title.narrative: CARE FOR SAM CHILDREN

description.narrative: Girls and boys under age five have increased and more equitable access to better quality nutrition services for early detection and treatment of severe acute malnutrition., which contributes to Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: New Element

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Girls and boys under age five have increased and more equitable access to better quality nutrition services for early detection andtreatment of severe acute malnutrition.

description.narrative: Despite challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, UNICEF-supported severe acute malnutrition (SAM) treatment provided through a network of 1,213 nutrition Outpatient Treatment (OTP) sites, improved nutrition performance indicators within Sphere standards at 95.9 per cent cure rate and 2.3;per cent defaulter rate in 2021, compared to 91 per cent cure rate and 5.0 per cent defaulter rate in 2020. The death rate of 0.2;per cent remained the same. The number of children with SAM treated increased from 201,055 children (102,538 girls) in 2020 to 241,108;children (131,249;girls) in 2021.; | Status:On-track | As-of Date:28/12/2021
